awd_titl_txt: Type II: UTSA CITE NSF I-Corps Site Proposal
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Texas (UTSA) proposes to renew their NSF I-Corps Site with additional goals of developing novel Intellectual Property (IP) policies that promulgate faculty and student involvement in launching technology ventures from the lab and bringing industry partners to campus. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

In addition to fulfilling the Site goals, UTSA is also studying and working with I-Corps teams to develop a deeper understanding of the educational constructs associated with identifying and nurturing nascent technology entrepreneurs. Together these suggest new paradigms for designing technology commercialization programs and their impact on university-industry innovation ecosystems. 

The SITE at UTSA has broader impacts that include the creation of a transformational and progressive entrepreneurial ecosystem within the university environment that is essential to foster, support, develop, and commercialize new technologies. Such an ecosystem will not only help to change academic mindsets and cultures, but also result in higher competitiveness in global markets, increased external funding via follow-up research dollars, an enhanced educational environment for students and faculty, increased marketability of UT graduates, and greater financial returns to the university and community via technology commercialization. In addition, as a minority serving institution with a focus on veterans, UTSA has been very successful in achieving diversity among their teams. With continued support and NSF I-Corps designation, the CITE will expand its network of partnerships through the I-Corps Nodes, the NIN, and the growing number of regional partners.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Innovation, Technology and Entrepreneurship (CITE) at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) was a conduit for I-Corps site programming sustained through funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to promote technology entrepreneurship training for students, faculty and researchers to foster the growth of new technology-based ventures. Towards the organized programming within this project, was the intentional establishment of various training, testing and support measures for engaging an entrepreneurial mindset in technology focused teams, and expanding the pool of technology and entrepreneurial partners and projects to be representative of the UTSA community at large, reflecting a high proportion of students traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, first-generation students, women and military veterans.

The NSF grant (1735874) was awarded in 2017 and was a close partnership between CITE and the Office of Commercialization and Innovation (OCI) at UTSA to organize customer-validated commercial development pathways for in-house technology. The activities to support training included Entrepreneurship Bootcamps; an online training platform called the Entrepreneurs Academy that has consistently enrolled students from 2020 onwards; and organized I-Corps regional workshops using the Lean LaunchPad methodologies. The Bootcamps and regional workshops catered to a mix of student and faculty teams with external business mentors providing training perspectives in the one-day bootcamps and team-specific mentorship over the month-long sequence of regional workshops. The Entrepreneurship Bootcamps which covered topics from ideation, value proposition discovery and testing, formation and funding at different stages of start-up ventures and teaming for successful navigation of scale-up trained around 1400 participants, and are incorporated into 4 structured courses at UTSA. The Entrepreneurs Academy platform was made broadly available online with a switch to remote learning in 2020-21, and has remained accessible to accommodate non-traditional students and trainees for self-paced learning, reaching 143 unique users completing the curriculum. The regional workshops trained 35 teams in validating their hypotheses through customer discovery, developing minimum viable products and corresponding business development plans. 9 of these teams received follow on I-Corps awards through the NSF’s national program, and 14 submitted small business/technology transfer related applications as a result of their training and validation.

The activities related to support provided to technology entrepreneurship teams was driven through specific OCI programs customized for I-Corps site teams. (1) Venture Mentoring Service (VMS) San Antonio, which leverages the Texas Venure Connect network to bring together diverse experts and experienced entrepreneurs as volunteer mentors for teams in the site programs to establish partnerships. For more mature technology validated teams, they were also partnered with technology sector experienced Entrepreneurs-in-Residence hosted by the OCI to potentially commercialize options on the intellectual property. (2) Individualized development, protection and management of intellectual property and technology readiness levels through licensing managers that saw 90 invention disclosures, 123 intellectual property filings over the course of this support translate to the generation of 28 business pitches, 11 startups created and 15 further technology licensing deals. Initial technology that was translated to commercialization focused on innovations in medical devices, energy, drug discovery and applications in signals/communications with a significant strength in cybersecurity and artificial intelligence emerging over the course of this project in terms of UTSA teams which required new strategies for better IP coverage and commercialization. (3) TechPOP funding and Innovation Lab resources formed direct bridge support for teams that completed the regional workshop milestones and progressed to generating minimum viable products, with the TechPOP funding supporting the process and the entrepreneurial leads, and the innovation lab providing the physical infrastructure and knowhow for rapid prototyping and testing when pertinent. 13 TechPOP awards were made and the Innovation Lab more broadly served around 100 student teams annually from 2020, those activities now continuing within the UTSA MakerSpace.

In addition to customer discovery and validation, the proving grounds for testing of technology was through two competitions: (1) the 100K Student Technology Venture competition which focused on primarily undergraduate student teams who had to present both technology and business thesis validation plans towards prizes comprising both financial and services towards establishing commercialization ventures and (2) the Big Rowdy Idea competitions, which were open to the broader community to include graduate students and faculty to pitch how deep technology could be applied for new business ventures, from which point teams were funneled into the training and support pipelines. 85 student teams participated in the 100K Student Technology Venture competition and 75 teams participated in the Big Rowdy Idea competition over the course of this project, with the competitions being conducted fully virtually over 2020-21.

The learning from this NSF grant also resulted in three publications related to networks and organization and its impacts on various aspects of technology entrepreneurship. The activities listed previously continue after the end of the grant within the programs offered by the OCI as well as the Najim Center at UTSA.      

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2025
Modified by: Teja Guda
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Center for Innovation, Technology and Entrepreneurship (CITE) at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) was a conduit for I-Corps site programming sustained through funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to promote technology entrepreneurship training for students, faculty and researchers to foster the growth of new technology-based ventures. Towards the organized programming within this project, was the intentional establishment of various training, testing and support measures for engaging an entrepreneurial mindset in technology focused teams, and expanding the pool of technology and entrepreneurial partners and projects to be representative of the UTSA community at large, reflecting a high proportion of students traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, first-generation students, women and military veterans.


The NSF grant (1735874) was awarded in 2017 and was a close partnership between CITE and the Office of Commercialization and Innovation (OCI) at UTSA to organize customer-validated commercial development pathways for in-house technology. The activities to support training included Entrepreneurship Bootcamps; an online training platform called the Entrepreneurs Academy that has consistently enrolled students from 2020 onwards; and organized I-Corps regional workshops using the Lean LaunchPad methodologies. The regional workshops trained 35 teams in validating their hypotheses through customer discovery, developing minimum viable products and corresponding business development plans. 9 of these teams received follow on I-Corps awards through the NSFs national program, and 14 submitted small business/technology transfer related applications as a result of their training and validation.


The activities related to support provided to technology entrepreneurship teams was driven through specific OCI programs customized for I-Corps site teams. (1) Venture Mentoring Service (VMS) San Antonio, which leverages the Texas Venure Connect network to bring together diverse experts and experienced entrepreneurs as volunteer mentors for teams in the site programs to establish partnerships. In addition to customer discovery and validation, the proving grounds for testing of technology was through two competitions: (1) the 100K Student Technology Venture competition which focused on primarily undergraduate student teams who had to present both technology and business thesis validation plans towards prizes comprising both financial and services towards establishing commercialization ventures and (2) the Big Rowdy Idea competitions, which were open to the broader community to include graduate students and faculty to pitch how deep technology could be applied for new business ventures, from which point teams were funneled into the training and support pipelines. 85 student teams participated in the 100K Student Technology Venture competition and 75 teams participated in the Big Rowdy Idea competition over the course of this project, with the competitions being conducted fully virtually over 2020-21.


The learning from this NSF grant also resulted in three publications related to networks and organization and its impacts on various aspects of technology entrepreneurship. The activities listed previously continue after the end of the grant within the programs offered by the OCI as well as the Najim Center at UTSA.
